421.title: European stocks dip after Trump’s visa crackdown, rate outlook in focus
421.body: By Nell Mackenzie and Ankur BanerjeeLONDON/SINGAPORE (Reuters) -European markets ticked lower on Monday, dragged by automakers’ profit warnings, while the dollar steadied as markets waited to see if optimism over the Federal Reserve’s easing monetary policy might be offset by geopolitical concerns.The pan-European STOXX 600 was little changed, with Spanish and German stocks down 0.6% and 0.5%, respectively.Luxury carmaker Porsche its parent Volkswagen both cut their profit forecasts after delaying the rollout of EV models due to weak demand.Meanwhile, MSCI’s broadest index of world stocks was little changed while India’s benchmark index slipped 0.2% after the Trump administration said it would ask companies to pay $100,000 for new H-1B worker visas, a blow to the tech sector that relies on skilled workers from India and China.In China, stocks were choppy even as U.S. President Donald Trump said he and Chinese President Xi Jinping had made progress on a TikTok agreement.The Shanghai Composite index .SSEC was up 0.2% while the blue-chip CSI300 index also rose 0.5%.India’s $283 billion information technology sector, which gets more than half its revenue from the U.S., will likely feel the pain in the near term.Trump last month doubled tariffs on imports from India to as much as 50%, partly due to New Delhi’s purchases of Russian oil."It’s a risk to operating costs and margins first of all. Obviously it could raise wages and labour costs a bit," said Kyle Rodda, senior financial analyst at Capital.com"Tech companies may also find themselves in a bind where they confront punitive measures if they look to offshore labour because they can’t find enough workers in the U.S."FED POLICY OUTLOOKOn the macroeconomic front, investors remain keen to gauge the U.S. monetary policy path after the Fed indicated a gradual easing phase in the future, with traders pricing in 44 basis points of easing in the two policy meetings left for the year.A host of policymakers is expected to speak in the week including John Williams, Thomas Barkin and Stephen Miran on Monday, and Raphael Bostic and Michelle Bowman on Tuesday along with Fed Chair Jerome Powell."Now it’s time for central bankers to come out and explain everything," said James Rossiter, head of global macro strategy at TD Securities, who hoped that over the next two days these remarks will help markets shape expectations more precisely.Data on the Fed’s preferred gauge of inflation is due on Friday that will also help set the tone for the near-term rate outlook.The expectation is for the core PCE price index to rise by 0.2% on a monthly basis, which would keep the annual rate steady at 2.9%, the same as in July, and above the 2.6% low it reached in April, according to Tony Sycamore, market analyst at IG."Although even a shallower rate-cutting cycle should, in theory, weigh on the U.S. dollar, the U.S. dollar short trade has become crowded," Sycamore said, adding the dollar index has lost downside momentum in recent months after a torrid start.The dollar index, which measures the U.S. currency against six other units, was down 0.2% at 97.54.U.S. stock futures eased with the S&P and Nasdaq futures both down 0.2%.The Japanese yen steadied at 147.87 per U.S. dollar after strengthening on Friday following the Bank of Japan’s hawkish hold where two board members voted against keeping interest rates steady.Oil prices climbed amid heightened geopolitical tensions in Europe and the Middle East, with Brent crude futures 34 cents higher at $67.02 a barrel. U.S. West Texas Intermediate futures rose 36 cents to $63.04. [O/R]Gold prices climbed, and were last up roughly 1% and at one point at a fresh record high of $3,719.65 per ounce. [GOL/]Most investors will find it hard to answer that question with total confidence. 423.title: Japan PM contender Hayashi backs BOJ rate-hike strategy
423.body: By Takaya Yamaguchi and Leika KiharaTOKYO (Reuters) -The Bank of Japan’s plan to gradually raise interest rates is broadly in line with the government’s thinking on economic policy, Yoshimasa Hayashi, top government spokesperson and a contender to become next prime minister, told Reuters.Asked whether he was concerned that any interest rate cuts by the U.S. Federal Reserve could hurt Japan’s export-reliant economy by pushing up the yen against the dollar, Hayashi said policymakers in Tokyo were moving past such assumptions.Japan’s traditional aversion to a strong yen, held mainly among exporters and at times a trigger for government intervention, had diminished, he said in an interview on Sunday."Conversely, we’ve seen the yen weaken which, coupled with rising oil costs since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, caused cost-push rather than demand-driven inflation," he said.Domestic wages and the price of rice were rising although the surge in import costs seen at the outset of the Ukraine war in 2022 had subsided, Hayashi said.The remarks highlight policymakers’ growing focus on the weak yen and subsequent rising inflation as the main problems facing Japan - a sea change from the orthodoxy of recent years that saw a strong yen and deflation as the biggest drags on growth.With inflation exceeding its 2% target for well over three years, BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda has signaled the bank’s resolve to gradually raise interest rates - still stuck at 0.5% - to levels deemed neutral to the economy."My understanding is that the Bank of Japan, in close communication with the government, is conducting monetary policy in a way that does not deviate much from our thinking," Hayashi said.His remarks came after the BOJ’s decision on Friday to start selling its risky asset holdings and a split vote on maintaining low rates that kept alive expectations of a near-term hike.Hayashi is among the candidates running in the ruling party’s leadership race to be held on October 4 after Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s decision earlier this month to step down.The next leader of the Liberal Democratic Party is likely to become prime minister as the party is by far the largest in the lower house of parliament. But the path is not guaranteed as the LDP lost its majorities in both houses under Ishiba.The LDP’s leadership contest has drawn strong market attention and led to a rise in government bond yields on the view the next leader could boost fiscal spending.If chosen as prime minister, Hayashi said his government would compile a package of measures to cushion the economic blow from rising living costs while boosting provisions for disaster relief.But the size of spending must take into account Japan’s "quite small" output gap and avoid issuance of deficit-covering debt, he said, ruling out the need for large-scale stimulus.The remark contrasts with that of Sanae Takaichi, another contender in the race who pledged fiscal expansion as part of a plan to reflate the economy.A veteran lawmaker whose portfolios include defence, foreign affairs and agriculture minister, Hayashi has served as chief cabinet secretary since December 2023 under then-premier Fumio Kishida and Ishiba.In a poll conducted over the weekend by Japan’s Mainichi daily on who would be best suited as LDP leader, Hayashi was third at 11% among party supporters, followed by 40% for Shinjiro Koizumi and 22% for Takaichi.AI computing powers are changing the stock market. 425.title: Oil News: Geopolitical Tensions Can’t Lift Crude Futures Above 200-Day Moving Average
425.body: Crude oil faces bearish pressure as prices fail at the 200-day moving average and OPEC supply rises, while geopolitical risks offer limited support.WTI OilLight crude oil futures were slightly higher Monday but gave back early gains after hitting resistance near the 200-day moving average, currently at $63.00. The failure at this level triggered a pullback toward Friday’s low at $62.20. A break below that threshold would mark a three-day losing streak and open the door to downside targets at $61.34, $61.10, and $60.77.At 09:37 GMT, Light Crude Oil Futures are trading $62.41, up $0.01 or +0.02%.While a move above the 200-day moving average could shift momentum to the upside, bulls still face overhead resistance at the 50-day moving average around $63.71 and a long-term pivot at $64.21. Without a clean break above these levels, crude remains technically vulnerable.Geopolitical developments in Europe provided limited support. Over the weekend, Russia launched strikes near Poland’s border, prompting a deployment of NATO aircraft to secure the airspace. Poland’s military responded quickly, while Estonia and Germany reported violations of NATO-controlled airspace by Russian jets. The United Nations Security Council is meeting Monday to address the airspace breaches.While these risks underscore ongoing concerns about European energy security, they have not been enough to offset near-term technical weakness or rising supply pressure.In the Middle East, fresh tensions emerged after four Western countries recognized a Palestinian state. The diplomatic move drew a sharp rebuke from Israel and raised fears of further unrest in the region — a key concern for oil traders watching for any disruptions from major producers.Fundamentally, the market remains under pressure from rising output. Iraq’s state oil marketer SOMO confirmed that crude exports averaged 3.38 million barrels per day in August, with September volumes projected to reach as high as 3.45 million bpd. The increases reflect a continued unwinding of voluntary OPEC+ production cuts.Meanwhile, inventories remain elevated. Analyst Tim Evans noted that while U.S. and Chinese strategic reserve builds have absorbed some excess, the surplus still weighs on near-term price potential.Crude oil remains technically weak as long as prices remain below the 200-day moving average near $63.00. Rising Iraqi supply and elevated inventories are capping rallies, while geopolitical support has failed to spark sustainable buying. A confirmed break below $62.20 would reinforce a bearish near-term outlook.More Information in our Economic Calendar.James Hyerczyk is a U.S. based seasoned technical analyst and educator with over 40 years of experience in market analysis and trading, specializing in chart patterns and price movement. He is the author of two books on technical analysis and has a background in both futures and stock markets.The Week Ahead: Markets Focus on PCE, Fed Speakers, and Consumer SentimentGold (XAUUSD) & Silver Price Forecast: Bulls Eye $3,725 and $44 on Fed Cut BoostGold (XAUUSD) and Silver Technical Analysis: Fed Cuts and Global Conflict Fuel Precious Metals RallyUS Dollar Price Forecast: Greenback Holds Gains Ahead of Powell Remarks GBP/USD and EUR/USDNatural Gas and Oil Forecast: Triangle Patterns Point to Breakout Amid OPEC+ Exports

426.title: Crude Oil Price Outlook – Crude Continues to Range
426.body: The crude oil market continues to see a lot of sideways action, as we are drifting a little be it lower in the early hours of Friday. At this point, we are still very much in range for this asset.WTI OilBrent OilThe light sweet crude oil market has fallen a bit to show signs of exhaustion and negativity again but then turned around to bounce a bit. At this point, I think we’re just hanging around in this consolidation area between the $62 level and the $65 level. So ultimately, we are just hanging around with the 50-day EMA offering resistance as well. Ultimately, I think you have a situation where crude oil is just simply trying to find some type of trading range, and I think maybe we’re in it between this $3 range pretty tight, but it seems to be holding.The Brent market is doing the same thing as it is sitting just below the 50 day EMA and it’s right in the middle of the larger consolidation area, with the $65 level offering support and the $69 level above being resistance. Ultimately, this market has been going sideways, and I think we’ve got a situation where the market is trying to sort out whether or not we are going to find enough momentum to break out, or if are we going to just simply bounce around here? I think the biggest problem that crude oil has right now is that the oversupply in the market is pretty heavy.The United States, Russia, and OPEC are all pumping massive amounts of oil. The demand is a problem as well, because quite frankly, the global economy seems to be sputtering just a little bit. And if that’s going to end up being the case, especially with the potential tariff problems, there are a lot of reasons to think that maybe transportation may not be taking so much in the way of crude oil demand to the market. We’ll just have to wait and see.For a look at all of today’s economic events, check out our economic calendar.Chris is a proprietary trader with more than 20 years of experience across various markets, including currencies, indices and commodities. As a senior analyst at FXEmpire since the website’s early days, he offers readers advanced market perspectives to navigate today’s financial landscape with confidence.The Week Ahead: Markets Focus on PCE, Fed Speakers, and Consumer SentimentGold (XAUUSD) & Silver Price Forecast: Bulls Eye $3,725 and $44 on Fed Cut BoostGold (XAUUSD) and Silver Technical Analysis: Fed Cuts and Global Conflict Fuel Precious Metals RallyOil News: Geopolitical Tensions Can’t Lift Crude Futures Above 200-Day Moving AverageNatural Gas and Oil Forecast: Triangle Patterns Point to Breakout Amid OPEC+ Exports

427.title: Natural Gas, WTI Oil, Brent Oil Forecasts – Oil Pulls Back As Traders Focus On The EIA Report
427.body: Natural GasWTI OilBrent OilNatural gas is losing ground as traders take profits after the recent move. Weather forecasts indicate that demand will stay moderate in the upcoming days, which may provide some support to the market.A move above the 50 MA at $3.14 will push natural gas towards the resistance level at $3.25 – $3.30.WTI oil pulled back as traders reacted to the EIA report, which indicated that crude inventories declined by -9.3 million barrels from the previous week.In case WTI oil manages to settle abvoe the 50 MA at $64.86, it will head towards the resistance at $66.00 – $66.50.Brent oil continues its attempts to settle above the resistance level, which is located in the $67.50 – $68.00 range.In case Brent oil settles above $68.00, it will move towards the resistance level at $71.00 – $71.50.For a look at all of today’s economic events, check out our economic calendar.Vladimir is an independent trader, with over 18 years of experience in the financial markets. His expertise spans a wide range of instruments like stocks, futures, forex, indices, and commodities, forecasting both long-term and short-term market movements.The Week Ahead: Markets Focus on PCE, Fed Speakers, and Consumer SentimentGold (XAUUSD) & Silver Price Forecast: Bulls Eye $3,725 and $44 on Fed Cut BoostGold (XAUUSD) and Silver Technical Analysis: Fed Cuts and Global Conflict Fuel Precious Metals RallyOil News: Geopolitical Tensions Can’t Lift Crude Futures Above 200-Day Moving AverageNatural Gas and Oil Forecast: Triangle Patterns Point to Breakout Amid OPEC+ Exports

428.title: Oil prices little changed as Russia, Mideast concerns offset by oversupply worry
428.body: By Shadia NasrallaLONDON (Reuters) -Oil prices were little changed on Monday as concerns over Russia and the Middle East were countered by oversupply jitters.Brent crude oil futures, which have traded between around $65.50 and $69 a barrel since early August, dipped 12 cents, or 0.2%, to $66.56 a barrel by 1000 GMT while the U.S. West Texas Intermediate crude contract for October was at $62.65 a barrel, down 3 cents, or 0.1%.The October WTI contract expires on Monday and the more active November contract fell 18 cents, or 0.3%, to $62.22 a barrel.Polish and allied aircraft were deployed early on Saturday to ensure the safety of Polish airspace after Russia launched airstrikes targeting western Ukraine near the border with Poland, armed forces of the NATO-member country said.The deployment came after three Russian military jets violated NATO Estonia’s airspace for 12 minutes on Friday.In the Middle East, four Western nations recognised a Palestinian state, prompting a furious response from Israel and adding to jitters in the key oil-producing region.Brent and WTI settled down more than 1% on Friday to mark a slight decline last week as worries about large supplies and declining demand weighed on sentiment."The setup for the oil market is that global oil demand is set to taper off from Q3 to Q4 and again to Q1-26. At the same time production by OPEC+ is on a rising path," said SEB analysts."The big question is of course if China will stockpile the increasing surplus or whether the oil price will be pushed lower into the 50ies. We believe the latter."Iraq, OPEC’s second-largest producer, has increased oil exports under an OPEC+ agreement, state oil marketer SOMO said on Sunday.SOMO expects September’s average exports to range from 3.4 million to 3.45 million bpd.Iraq has also given preliminary approval to a plan to resume pipeline oil exports from its semi-autonomous Kurdistan region through Turkey following delays to a hoped-for restart, sources familiar with the talks told Reuters.The best opportunities often hide in plain sight—buried among thousands of stocks you'd never have time to research individually. 429.title: Dollar Strength and Global Oil Glut Fears Weigh on Crude Prices
429.body: October WTI crude oil (CLV25) today is down -0.48 (-0.75%), and October RBOB gasoline (RBV25) is down -0.0243 (-1.20%).Crude oil and gasoline prices are under pressure today from a stronger dollar (DXY00).  Also, the outlook for a global oil supply glut is undercutting crude prices.  Losses in crude are limited today as Ukraine ramped up its attacks against Russian refineries, which threatens to tighten global oil supplies.  Also, better-than-expected US economic news today is supportive of energy demand and crude prices.  In addition, today's rally in the S&P 500 to a new record high shows confidence in the economic outlook that is bullish for energy demand.  Strength in the dollar today is limiting gains in crude prices.  Concerns about a global oil glut are bearish for crude prices after the International Energy Agency (IEA) last Thursday boosted its 2026 global crude surplus estimate to 3.33 million bpd, +360,000 bpd higher than anticipated in August, citing plans by OPEC+ to revive its crude production.Better-than-expected US economic news today is supportive of energy demand and crude prices.   Weekly initial unemployment claims fell by -33,000 to 231,000, showing a stronger labor market than expectations of 240,000.  Also, the Sep Philadelphia Fed business outlook survey rose +23.5 to an 8-month high of 23.2, stronger than expectations of 1.7.Ukraine has stepped up its attacks on Russian refineries and oil infrastructure, which is bullish for crude prices as it curbs Russian crude exports and tightens global oil supplies.  Ukraine attacked Russia's Salavat and Volograd oil refineries today, halting around 300,000 bpd of refining capacity.  On Tuesday, Russia's Transneft Pipeline, which handles more than 80% of the country's oil, restricted the ability to store crude.  Also, the Kirishi refinery, one of Russia's biggest refineries that has an annual processing capacity of over 20 million tons, halted crude processing after damage caused by a Ukrainian drone attack on Sunday.  In addition, Ukrainian drone attacks have damaged Russian oil infrastructure and crude-exporting hubs along Russia's Baltic Coast.  Ukrainian drone and missile attacks on Russian refineries have curbed Russia's crude-processing runs to 4.98 million bpd in the first three days of September, the lowest monthly average in over 3.25 years.  Crude prices have support on concerns that the ongoing war in Ukraine could lead to additional sanctions on Russian energy exports, reducing global oil supplies.  President Trump said last Friday that his patience with Russian President Putin was "running out fast" for continuing the war in Ukraine, and he threatened new economic sanctions against Russia.  The US proposed that the Group of Seven allies impose tariffs as high as 100% on China and India for their purchases of Russian oil in an effort to convince Russia to end the war in Ukraine.A decrease in crude oil held worldwide on tankers is bullish for oil prices.  Vortexa reported Monday that crude oil stored on tankers that have been stationary for at least seven days fell by -7.2% w/w to 67.96 million bbl in the week ended September 12.Crude prices also have support after OPEC+ agreed on September 7 to raise its crude production by 137,000 bpd, starting in October.  This is less than the 547,000 bpd increase the group decided to boost output in September and August.  OPEC+ also said restarting the remainder of the 1.66 million bpd crude production it had idled will be contingent on "evolving market conditions."  OPEC+ is boosting output to reverse the 2-year-long production cut, gradually restoring a total of 2.2 million bpd of production by September 2026.  OPEC Aug crude production rose by +400,000 bpd to 28.55 million bpd, the highest in over two years.Wednesday's EIA report showed that (1) US crude oil inventories as of September 12 were -4.7% below the seasonal 5-year average, (2) gasoline inventories were -1.6% below the seasonal 5-year average, and (3) distillate inventories were -7.4% below the 5-year seasonal average.  US crude oil production in the week ending September 12 fell by -0.1% w/w to 13.482 million bpd, modestly below the record high of 13.631 million bpd posted in the week of 12/6/2024.Baker Hughes reported last Friday that the number of active US oil rigs in the week ending September 12 rose by +2 to 416 rigs, just above the 4-year low of 410 rigs from August 1.  Over the past 2.5 years, the number of US oil rigs has fallen sharply from the 5.5-year high of 627 rigs reported in December 2022.

430.title: India’s August infrastructure output grows 6.3% y/y
430.body: NEW DELHI (Reuters) -India’s infrastructure output rose 6.3% year-on-year in August, backed by growth in steel, coal and cement production, government data showed on Monday.The index, which tracks activity across eight sectors and makes up 40% of the country’s industrial production, grew at a revised 3.7% in July.KEY NUMBERS* Crude oil output fell 1.2% year-on-year in August against a fall of 1.3% in July* Natural gas production declined 2.2% year-on-year after a fall of 3.2% in July* Cement output rose 6.1% in August compared with a revised growth of 11.6% year-on-year in July* Steel production rose 14.2% after a revised 16.6% year-on-year increase in July* Fertiliser production rose 4.6% year-on-year in August after a growth of 2% in July* Coal production grew 11.4% year-on-year compared with a fall of 12.3% in July* Electricity generation grew 3.1% year-on-year in August against a revised 3.7% increase in July* Refinery products output grew 3% in August against a revised 1.1% fall in July* Infrastructure output grew 2.8% year-on-year in April-August against a growth of 4.6% a year agoThe best opportunities often hide in plain sight—buried among thousands of stocks you'd never have time to research individually. 431.title: Oil prices slip as robust supply outweighs Fed cut
431.body: (Corrects to show Brent and WTI prices fell for the week, not rose for a second consecutive week, in paragraph 3)By Erwin SebaHOUSTON (Reuters) -Oil prices dropped on Friday as worries about large supplies and declining demand outweighed expectations that the year’s first interest-rate cut by the U.S. Federal Reserve would trigger more consumption. Brent crude futures settled at $66.68 a barrel, down 76 cents or 1.1%. U.S. West Texas Intermediate futures finished at $62.68, down 89 cents or 1.4%.Both benchmarks fell for the week."Oil supplies continue to remain robust and OPEC is reducing its oil production cuts," said Andrew Lipow, president of Lipow Oil Associates. "We haven’t seen an impact on Russian crude oil exports" from sanctions.The Fed cut its policy rate by a quarter of a percentage point on Wednesday and indicated that more cuts would follow as it responded to signs of weakness in the U.S. jobs market. Lower borrowing costs typically boost demand for oil and push prices higher. John Kilduff, partner with Again Capital, said future Fed rate cuts of a quarter of a percentage point would likely not boost oil markets because they would further weaken the dollar, making oil more expensive to buy."The Fed will have to be more aggressive than they have been," Kilduff said. "We need a 50 (basis-point increase) to boost demand. The Fed’s action is not translating to growth for the crude market due to underlying market fundamentals."On the demand side, all energy agencies, including the U.S. Energy Information Administration, have signaled concern about weakening demand, tempering expectations of significant near-term price upside, said Priyanka Sachdeva, an analyst at Phillip Nova. Lipow also saw effects on the demand side."The refinery turnaround season will further reduce demand," he said.Refineries shut production units in the spring and fall for overhauls, called turnarounds. A higher-than-expected increase of 4 million barrels to U.S. distillate stockpiles raised worries over demand in the world’s top oil consumer and pressured prices. [EIA/S]The latest economic data added to concerns, with the U.S. jobs market softening while single-family homebuilding plunged to a multi-year low in August, discouraged by a glut of unsold new houses. AI computing powers are changing the stock market. 432.title: Sasol downgraded at Morgan Stanley on weak cash flow outlook
432.body: Investing.com -- Morgan Stanley cut its rating on Sasol Ltd to Equal-weight from Overweight, warning that recent share gains are masking weak free cash flow prospects and long-term risks to its South African business.The brokerege also lowered its price target to R120 from R140.“Sasol has outperformed peers over various time periods albeit off a highly depressed base,” Morgan Stanley said. The rally was supported by improved second-half cash flow, progress on cost-cutting projects, and optimism around China’s policy measures.But the brokerage said much of the debt reduction in fiscal 2025 came from temporary factors, including a Transnet payment, working capital unwind and dividend receipts. “Near-term FCF generation prospects remain poor in our view,” it said, forecasting free cash flow of R5 to R6 per share in 2026 and 2027, leaving the stock trading at about 20 times cash flow.There are headwinds from weaker oil and chemical markets, also a stronger rand and ongoing structural issues. “Our key concern remains feedstock – both the depletion in Mozambique gas supply and the availability or cost of replacement coal given the ongoing structural decline in Sasol’s own production volumes,” analysts at Morgan Stanley said. Rising South African carbon taxes will also weigh on returns, it added.While refining margins are providing some offset, the bank said longer-term risks will erode much of Sasol’s progress. It cut earnings forecasts by nearly a fifth for 2026 and 2027, citing lower coal and chemical volumes and currency strength.At R117 per share, Sasol is now trading in line with spot oil prices for the first time in years, Morgan Stanley noted, but cautioned that the macro backdrop leaves “caution warranted.”Get an up-to-the-minute summary from WarrenAI, our powerful AI financial researcher. 434.title: Crude Prices Undercut by Dollar Strength and Possible Larger Global Oil Supplies
434.body: October WTI crude oil (CLV25) today closed down -0.55 (-0.87%), and October RBOB gasoline (RBV25) closed down -0.0309 (-1.54%).Crude oil and gasoline prices are moving lower today due to strength in the dollar (DXY00).  Also, the outlook for additional global oil supplies is bearish for crude prices after Reuters reported that Iraq is near a deal to resume crude oil exports from its Kurdistan region to Turkey.  Losses in crude are limited as Ukraine ramped up its attacks against Russian refineries, which threaten to tighten global oil supplies.  Crude prices came under pressure today after Reuters reported that Iraq has given preliminary approval to a plan to resume pipeline oil exports from its Kurdistan region through Turkey.  The deal could add at least 230,000 bpd of fresh oil supplies to global markets.  Concerns about a global oil glut are bearish for crude prices after the International Energy Agency (IEA) last Thursday boosted its 2026 global crude surplus estimate to 3.33 million bpd, +360,000 bpd higher than anticipated in August, citing plans by OPEC+ to revive its crude production.Ukraine has stepped up its attacks on Russian refineries and oil infrastructure, which is bullish for crude prices as it curbs Russian crude exports and tightens global oil supplies.  Ukraine attacked Russia's Salavat and Volograd oil refineries on Thursday, halting around 300,000 bpd of refining capacity.  On Tuesday, Russia's Transneft Pipeline, which handles more than 80% of the country's oil, restricted the ability to store crude.  Also, the Kirishi refinery, one of Russia's biggest refineries that has an annual processing capacity of over 20 million tons, halted crude processing after damage caused by a Ukrainian drone attack on Sunday.  In addition, Ukrainian drone attacks have damaged Russian oil infrastructure and crude-exporting hubs along Russia's Baltic Coast.  Ukrainian drone and missile attacks on Russian refineries have curbed Russia's crude-processing runs to 4.98 million bpd in the first three days of September, the lowest monthly average in over 3.25 years.  Crude prices have support on concerns that the ongoing war in Ukraine could lead to additional sanctions on Russian energy exports, reducing global oil supplies.  President Trump said last Friday that his patience with Russian President Putin was "running out fast" for continuing the war in Ukraine, and he threatened new economic sanctions against Russia.  The US proposed that the Group of Seven allies impose tariffs as high as 100% on China and India for their purchases of Russian oil in an effort to convince Russia to end the war in Ukraine.A decrease in crude oil held worldwide on tankers is bullish for oil prices.  Vortexa reported Monday that crude oil stored on tankers that have been stationary for at least seven days fell by -7.2% w/w to 67.96 million bbl in the week ended September 12.Crude prices also have support after OPEC+ agreed on September 7 to raise its crude production by 137,000 bpd, starting in October.  This is less than the 547,000 bpd increase the group decided to boost output in September and August.  OPEC+ also said restarting the remainder of the 1.66 million bpd crude production it had idled will be contingent on "evolving market conditions."  OPEC+ is boosting output to reverse the 2-year-long production cut, gradually restoring a total of 2.2 million bpd of production by September 2026.  OPEC Aug crude production rose by +400,000 bpd to 28.55 million bpd, the highest in over two years.Wednesday's EIA report showed that (1) US crude oil inventories as of September 12 were -4.7% below the seasonal 5-year average, (2) gasoline inventories were -1.6% below the seasonal 5-year average, and (3) distillate inventories were -7.4% below the 5-year seasonal average.  US crude oil production in the week ending September 12 fell by -0.1% w/w to 13.482 million bpd, modestly below the record high of 13.631 million bpd posted in the week of 12/6/2024.Baker Hughes reported last Friday that the number of active US oil rigs in the week ending September 12 rose by +2 to 416 rigs, just above the 4-year low of 410 rigs from August 1.  Over the past 2.5 years, the number of US oil rigs has fallen sharply from the 5.5-year high of 627 rigs reported in December 2022.

1.summary: The analysis of recent news articles suggests a bearish outlook for WTI crude oil prices in both the short and medium term. Several factors contribute to this prediction. Primarily, concerns about oversupply are consistently highlighted, with the IEA projecting a faster rise in world oil supply than previously expected, driven by increased output from OPEC+ and other nations. Additionally, weaker-than-expected U.S. demand, reflected in rising crude inventories and concerns about the strength of the U.S. economy, further contributes to the downward pressure on prices. While geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Ukraine provide some support, their impact appears to be diminishing in the face of strong supply fundamentals. China's stockpiling efforts offer some price support, but not enough to offset the bearish sentiment. The technical analysis also suggests bearish momentum.

2.summary: The oil market is currently facing mixed signals. Oversupply concerns, driven by rising production from OPEC+ and other nations as highlighted by the IEA, are weighing on prices. Weakening US demand, indicated by rising crude inventories and jobless claims, further contributes to this downward pressure. However, geopolitical risks stemming from conflicts in the Middle East and Ukraine, along with potential sanctions on Russian oil, provide some support. The split between OPEC's optimistic demand outlook and IEA's oversupply forecast creates uncertainty. Recent price action indicates a bearish tilt, with prices falling despite geopolitical tensions. China's stockpiling efforts offer some support, but overall, the market appears to be heading towards a period of lower prices due to increasing supply outpacing demand. Recent trading data shows a short term gain which can be attributed as the market correcting from the steep losses, but the mid term trend seems bearish.

3.summary: The short-term forecast is neutral, influenced by offsetting factors. Oversupply concerns and weaker U.S. demand exert downward pressure, while geopolitical risks offer some support. The medium-term forecast is slightly bearish, as the IEA anticipates a rapid rise in global oil supply, potentially leading to an oversupplied market despite OPEC's unchanged demand forecasts. Recent news of rising US crude stocks and increased output from OPEC+ members support this bearish outlook. The market is toggling between these pressures, but the risk of a tumble in oil prices may increase.

4.summary: WTI crude oil prices experienced a bounce today, driven by renewed concerns over Russian oil supply disruptions following Ukrainian drone attacks on key Russian export terminals. These geopolitical factors are supporting prices in the short term. However, conflicting signals regarding global supply and demand, with the IEA forecasting a rapid rise in supply and a potential surplus in 2026, alongside OPEC's relatively higher demand growth outlook, create uncertainty in the medium term. Increased US crude inventories and potential sanctions on Russian oil buyers are also key factors to monitor. Therefore, the forecast is moderately positive in the short term and neutral in the medium term.

5.summary: WTI crude oil prices experienced a surge today due to escalating geopolitical tensions. Reports of Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian oil export hubs and potential tariffs on China and India, major Russian oil buyers, have disrupted supply expectations, supporting prices in the short term. However, conflicting reports from IEA and OPEC, with the IEA forecasting a rapid rise in global oil supply and OPEC maintaining a higher demand forecast, create uncertainty in the medium term, suggesting a neutral outlook. Concerns over oversupply and potentially weakening US demand also exert downward pressure, tempering the bullish sentiment.

6.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to increase in the short and medium term. This is mainly due to geopolitical tensions, particularly Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian oil infrastructure and the potential for further sanctions on Russia. These factors outweigh concerns about oversupply and weaker U.S. demand. Additionally, positive technical signals, such as prices holding above key support levels, contribute to the upward forecast. However, conflicting reports from OPEC and IEA, and concerns about a potential global supply glut limit the forecast to a moderate increase.

7.summary: WTI crude oil prices experienced a rebound on September 12th, driven by concerns over potential supply disruptions stemming from geopolitical tensions, particularly those involving Russia and Ukraine, and the Middle East. The market remains sensitive to such risks, with Ukrainian drone strikes on Russian oil infrastructure and potential new sanctions on Russian oil buyers providing upward price pressure. The historical data shows a fluctuating trend with an overall average around 63 dollars per barrel. However, oversupply worries, as highlighted by the IEA's report, and weak economic data from the US (concerning jobless claims and sticky inflation) could limit gains. The forecasts from OPEC and the IEA differ significantly, adding to market uncertainty, but the most recent trend is mildly positive. China's continued stockpiling provides underlying support. Given these counteracting forces, a cautiously optimistic outlook is warranted for both the short and medium term.

8.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to increase in the short and medium term. Geopolitical tensions, particularly those related to Russia and Ukraine, including sanctions and drone attacks on Russian ports, are a key driver of upward pressure. Additionally, the U.S. Treasury's call for tariffs on China and India for purchasing Russian oil, if implemented, could further tighten global supplies. Support for oil prices is also coming from OPEC+'s managed output increases and the potential for U.S. Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. Offsetting these bullish factors are concerns about oversupply and weaker U.S. demand, as indicated by rising U.S. crude inventories and reports from the IEA forecasting a rapid rise in global oil supply. Market technicals also point to a bottom forming around the $62 level.

9.summary: In the short term, WTI crude oil prices are expected to increase. This forecast is based on the latest news indicating a Ukrainian drone attack on a Russian port that suspended loadings. The US is urging G7 sanctions on Russian oil, and concerns persist about smaller Russian crude exports. The previous trading day saw a 0.51% increase, providing immediate upward momentum. For the medium term, a positive trend is also anticipated. The factors supporting this trend are continued geopolitical tensions related to Russia and Ukraine, the potential for supply disruptions due to attacks on Russian infrastructure, and the US push for tariffs on countries purchasing Russian oil. Despite concerns about oversupply and weaker US demand, the balance of factors suggests a moderate increase in WTI prices over the coming week.

10.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to rise in the short and medium term. The key factors driving this prediction are: 1) Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, leading to potential supply disruptions. These attacks targeted major oil export terminals and refineries, causing immediate price increases. 2) Anticipation of an interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve, which is expected to weaken the dollar and boost economic activity, supporting oil demand. 3) President Trump's pressure on Europe to reduce Russian oil imports, which could further tighten global supplies. However, potential headwinds include concerns over slowing U.S. demand, expectations of a global surplus as OPEC+ boosts production, and a trend of slowing growth in U.S. oil production among smaller producers.

11.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to rise in the short and medium term. The primary driver for this is the ongoing Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, which have the potential to disrupt Russian oil supply and place upward pressure on prices. The Fed decision to cut interest rates is also expected to support prices. Offsetting factors include concerns about slowing U.S. demand and expectations of a global surplus. The historical data indicates a mixed trend, with recent gains supported by supply concerns.

12.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to rise slightly in the short and medium term. Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure continue to disrupt supply, adding upward pressure on prices. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates, which should boost economic activity and support oil demand. However, rising U.S. oil production and concerns over global oversupply will likely limit gains.

13.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to experience a slight upward trend in both the short and medium term. This forecast is based on recent news indicating rising geopolitical risks due to Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, which are disrupting Russian crude and fuel exports and potential supply disruptions. The anticipation of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut is also contributing to this upward pressure. However, concerns about a potential global oversupply and slowing U.S. demand are tempering these gains.

14.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to rise in the short and medium term. The primary driver is the increased geopolitical risk due to Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, which could disrupt Russian oil supply. Additional factors supporting the upward trend include potential new sanctions on Russia and a possible interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve, which could weaken the dollar and stimulate economic activity. However, concerns about oversupply from OPEC+ and weaker-than-expected economic data in the U.S. could limit gains.

15.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to rise in the short and medium term. Geopolitical tensions due to Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, coupled with potential new sanctions and a possible Fed rate cut, are likely to exert upward pressure on prices. Ongoing US-China trade talks could also contribute to price volatility, depending on their outcome. Historical data indicates a recent upward trend.

16.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to increase slightly in the short and medium term. The recent attacks on Russian energy infrastructure are disrupting supply, while the potential for further sanctions from the U.S. and possible tariffs on China and India could further limit global supplies. Also, the expectations of a FED rate cut tends to boost economic activity and could help support oil demand in the coming months.

17.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to increase in the short and medium term. This is mainly driven by the recent attacks on Russian energy facilities, which have disrupted crude and fuel exports. Other factors include the potential for new sanctions on Russia and the possibility of a Fed rate cut, which could boost fuel demand. However, there are also some concerns about oversupply and weaker economic data from China, which could weigh on prices.

18.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to rise in the short and medium term due to geopolitical tensions, particularly Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, which raise concerns about supply disruptions. President Trump's willingness to impose sanctions on Russia, if NATO nations cease purchasing Russian oil, adds further upward pressure. Concerns about oversupply, as OPEC+ plans to increase output, and potential interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, which could boost fuel demand, create uncertainty but the rising geopolitical tensions seem to be dominant in the short term.

19.summary:
In the short term, WTI prices are likely to experience a slight upward trend. This is primarily driven by the ongoing geopolitical tensions related to Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, which raise concerns about potential supply disruptions. The anticipation of a Federal Reserve rate cut also contributes to the upward pressure, as lower rates could stimulate economic activity and increase oil demand. However, factors like rising OPEC+ production and potentially weaker economic data from the U.S. could limit gains. Overall, the news flow suggests a slightly positive outlook for WTI prices in the short term.

In the medium term, a moderate upward trend is also expected. The key drivers are the continuing geopolitical risks and the potential for further sanctions on Russia, which could constrain global oil supplies. The market also anticipates a Federal Reserve rate cut, which generally boosts fuel demand. However, the potential for a "big surplus" in the oil market later in the year, driven by rising OPEC+ production, and concerns about global economic growth could limit any significant price increases. Overall, the balance of factors points to a slightly positive medium-term outlook, but with some uncertainty due to supply and demand dynamics.

20.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to experience a slight upward trend in both the short and medium term. This is primarily driven by concerns over potential supply disruptions due to Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, and the anticipation of a U.S. Federal Reserve interest rate cut. Despite concerns about oversupply from OPEC+ and weaker economic data, the geopolitical tensions and the potential for increased fuel demand due to lower interest rates provide a supportive backdrop for prices.

21.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to rise in the short and medium term. The analysis indicates a bullish trend driven by concerns over potential supply disruptions due to Ukrainian attacks on Russian oil infrastructure. This is coupled with expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut, which typically boosts fuel demand and the accelerated decline in global oil and gas fields requiring more investment. While there are counter-pressures, such as potential oversupply from OPEC+ and weaker economic data, the prevailing sentiment is bullish.

22.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to rise in the short and medium term. Several factors contribute to this outlook. First, Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian oil refineries continue to disrupt supply, creating upward pressure on prices. Second, there's anticipation of a potential interest rate cut by the U.S. Federal Reserve, which could boost economic activity and increase oil demand. However, the rising output from OPEC+ and concerns about a potential global oil surplus could limit price gains.

23.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to trend slightly higher in the short and medium term. This forecast is primarily driven by the intensifying Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, which are causing concerns about supply disruptions. The anticipation of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut is also expected to provide some support to prices. However, these upward pressures are being partially offset by concerns about a potential oversupply in the global oil market, as OPEC+ plans to increase production.

24.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to rise slightly in the short and medium term. Recent Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian oil infrastructure are causing concerns about potential supply disruptions, pushing prices upward. The market also expects a rate cut from the Federal Reserve, which could boost economic activity and fuel demand. However, increasing output from OPEC+ and a potential global oil surplus could limit gains. The Fed meeting will provide further clarity on monetary policy and its potential impact on oil demand.

25.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to experience a slightly positive trend in both the short and medium term. This forecast is based on several factors, including geopolitical tensions stemming from Ukrainian attacks on Russian oil infrastructure, which continue to pose supply disruption risks. Additionally, expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the U.S. Federal Reserve are factored in, which could stimulate the economy and boost fuel demand. Concerns about global oversupply and weaker economic data from China are potential headwinds, but the positive factors seem to outweigh the negatives at this time. Market participants await the EIA report on Wednesday for confirmation of inventory declines.

26.summary: Crude oil prices face mixed signals. Geopolitical tensions, particularly Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, provide upward pressure. Additionally, the widely anticipated Fed rate cut could boost demand. However, increasing OPEC+ production and concerns about global economic growth, particularly in China, pose downside risks. Recent price action shows some consolidation, and the market is awaiting further clarity from the Fed's meeting and inventory data. Historical data shows a decrease today after a rally.

27.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to decrease slightly in the short term, as reflected by the day's closing price and downward trend, while positive geopolitical forces, attacks on Russian oil infrastructure and a possible FED rate cut, might lead to an increase in the next week.

28.summary: WTI crude oil prices are facing downward pressure in the short term due to the recent Fed rate decision and a weaker-than-expected US economic outlook. Geopolitical risks related to Ukrainian attacks on Russian oil infrastructure are providing some support, but increasing OPEC+ output raises concerns about a global supply overhang. The market is closely watching US inventory data, which is expected to show a draw in crude stockpiles but builds in gasoline and distillate supplies. The outlook for the medium term remains neutral due to these conflicting factors.

29.summary: WTI crude oil prices are facing mixed signals. The ongoing Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian refineries introduce supply concerns, providing upward pressure. However, a potential Fed rate cut, while generally supportive, is overshadowed by concerns about the overall health of the U.S. economy and the possibility of a large surplus ahead due to increasing OPEC+ output. Recent price action shows a decline after a period of gains. The sanctions on Iranian oil sales via cryptocurrency networks also adds uncertainty, though its impact is likely limited. Based on the immediate price action and the balance of bullish and bearish factors, a slight downward pressure is expected in the short term, with a neutral outlook for the medium term.

30.summary: WTI crude oil prices are facing mixed signals. Short-term: A slight drop in price today, a Fed rate decision that may or may not boost demand, and continuing Ukrainian attacks on Russian oil infrastructure create uncertainty, resulting in a downward pressure for the short term. Medium-term: Potential supply disruptions from Russian attacks and OPEC+ production decisions are counteracted by weaker global economic data and potential increases in OPEC+ output. The range-bound trading pattern of the last month indicates a period of consolidation. Therefore the medium term outlook is neutral.

31.summary: WTI crude oil prices are influenced by several factors that create a mixed outlook. Geopolitical tensions, particularly Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, provide upward pressure due to supply disruption risks. Counterbalancing this, global economic uncertainty and increased OPEC+ production could weigh on prices. The anticipated Fed rate cut introduces an element of support by potentially boosting economic activity and demand. However, concerns about sticky inflation and the Fed's future rate outlook add uncertainty. Sanctions against Iran continue and Vitol and Glencore may bid for Chevron's stake. Overall, the market is finely balanced, leading to a neutral short-term outlook but leaning towards a slightly positive medium-term trend.

32.summary: WTI crude oil prices are influenced by several conflicting factors. Downward pressure is created by the expected Fed rate cut, and the sanctions and associated risk on Iranian and Russian oil. The attacks on Russian oil infrastructure, particularly refineries, support prices due to concerns about supply disruptions. The technical analysis suggests consolidation with potential for a breakout to the upside. The historical data also shows considerable fluctuations.

33.summary: WTI crude oil prices are influenced by several factors. Geopolitical risks, particularly Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, create upward pressure due to potential supply disruptions. The expected Federal Reserve rate cut is anticipated to boost economic activity and, consequently, fuel demand. However, increasing OPEC+ output and concerns about a global supply overhang temper bullish conviction. Sanctions on Iranian oil sales and discussions about OPEC+ production capacity add further complexity. Yesterday's close confirms the neutral trend in the short term.

34.summary: The short-term forecast is neutral due to mixed signals. While ongoing geopolitical tensions and Ukrainian attacks on Russian refineries provide upward pressure, the market is awaiting the Fed's decision on interest rates, resulting in a wait-and-see approach. The medium-term forecast is slightly positive due to supply concerns stemming from the Russia-Ukraine conflict and potential for increased demand if the Fed cuts interest rates. Also, crude oil stocks have been declining, which may lend support to higher prices.

35.summary: WTI crude oil prices face mixed signals. On one hand, geopolitical tensions due to Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure are supporting prices. Additionally, expectations of a Fed rate cut could boost demand. However, concerns about a global supply glut and potential for further OPEC+ output increases may limit gains. The market is closely watching the Fed's decision and the EIA inventory data for further direction. Yesterday decrease the price. Therefore, prices are expected to remain range-bound in the short term and experience a slight upward trend in the medium term.

36.summary: WTI crude oil prices are likely to remain range-bound in the short term due to conflicting factors. Support is being provided by decreasing inventories and ongoing geopolitical tensions related to Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, which are raising supply concerns. However, this is balanced by concerns about global economic growth, expected interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Canada (which could also reflect economic weakness), and potential increases in OPEC+ output. The larger-than-expected draw in crude inventories should provide a base. In the medium term, a slight upward pressure is expected, as the market seems to tilt bullish due to the Ukrainian attacks on russian refineries, and expectation of rate cuts and the IEA data. Also the last closing prices confirms such trend.

37.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to remain neutral in the short term and experience a slight upward trend in the medium term. The Fed decision, EIA inventory data, and geopolitical tensions related to Ukraine and Russia are the primary factors influencing this forecast. The market is currently range-bound, but potential supply disruptions from Ukrainian attacks and the possibility of a Fed rate cut could provide some upward pressure. Historical data shows a choppy trend, but recent gains suggest potential bullish momentum.

38.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to show no clear trend in the short and medium term. The market is influenced by several conflicting factors: Ukrainian attacks on Russian refineries raise concerns about supply disruptions and provide upward pressure on prices. However, an expected interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve could stimulate demand, while concerns about a global oil glut, and increasing output from OPEC+, could limit gains. Recent US inventory data showing a large crude oil draw is a bullish signal, but rising distillate stockpiles suggest demand concerns. The Fed's rate decision and outlook will be key to the medium-term trend.

39.summary: WTI crude oil prices are influenced by several conflicting factors. Downward pressure is exerted by the expected Fed rate cut, concerns about US demand due to rising distillate stockpiles, and potential oversupply from OPEC+ increases. Counteracting this are supply concerns stemming from Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, which may lead to production cuts and reduced exports, as well as larger than expected drawdowns in US crude oil inventories. Geopolitical tensions also provide a floor for prices. The market is currently rangebound, with investors awaiting further clarity from the Fed meeting and EIA inventory data. Recent price data confirms this trend with a decrease in the price on 2025-09-17.

40.summary: WTI crude oil prices are influenced by several conflicting factors. On the bullish side, geopolitical tensions due to Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure continue to pose supply risks. Also, the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) reported a large decline in U.S. crude oil inventories, which supports prices. Expectations of a potential Fed rate cut, while seemingly priced in already, could stimulate economic activity and fuel demand. On the bearish side, there are concerns about weaker U.S. diesel demand, as shown by increased distillate stockpiles. The fact that the rate cut seems fully priced in means this factor will not influence oil prices. A strong dollar is also an issue that has weighed on prices. Mixed economic data and concerns about a global supply glut due to increased OPEC+ production are also concerns that are keeping prices under pressure. Overall, the medium trend will be slightly upwards, due to supply disruption by Ukrainian attacks on Russia's energy infrastructure

41.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to decrease in the short term due to the recent EIA report showing an increase in distillate inventories, indicating weaker demand, and profit taking after FED's rate cut, as well as decrease in housing starts. However, the medium-term outlook is neutral. Support is provided by Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure which have been affecting refining capacity, as well as overall decline rate of oil fields, while some support is also from FED rate cut, along with the geopolitical scenario and draw in the U.S. crude inventories. The impact of a potential recession due to higher rates will be somewhat offset by cuts in output by OPEC+.

42.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to decrease in the short term based on the current closing price and recent trends. In the medium term, the outlook is neutral due to counteracting forces: geopolitical tensions from Ukrainian attacks on Russian infrastructure are pushing prices up, while increased OPEC+ production and a potential global supply glut are pushing prices down. The Fed's rate cut also has an unclear impact, with lower rates increasing demand but indicating economic concerns.

43.summary: The oil market is currently in a state of uncertainty, with mixed signals from various sources. The Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates has been factored into the short-term trend. However, there are continuing issues such as Russian supply disruptions and the potential for a global surplus, offsetting some of the upward pressure. WTI crude oil prices are expected to be slightly bearish in the short term because economic growth forecasts seem to be uncertain. Medium-term, a neutral position is maintained.

44.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to decrease in the short term due to the Federal Reserve's cautious stance on future rate cuts, which has raised concerns about the US economy. Also, an increase in distillate stockpiles coupled with falling demand. However, in the medium term, prices are expected to stabilize, as the market weighs ongoing geopolitical tensions and supply risks arising from the Russia-Ukraine conflict with the potential for increased demand spurred by future rate cuts.

45.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to experience a slight downward pressure in the short term due to concerns regarding the strength of the U.S. economy and an unexpected build in distillate inventories. The Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates, while potentially supportive, has been overshadowed by a cautious outlook from policymakers. Ongoing geopolitical tensions related to Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure and potential for new sanctions continue to provide some support, limiting significant price declines. In the medium term, the trend is predicted to be neutral, as the combination of geopolitical risks, and monetary policy offsets concerns related to oversupply.

46.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to experience downward pressure in the short term due to a combination of factors, including the Fed's less dovish stance after the rate cut, which raised concerns about the US economy. The mixed US inventory data, particularly the rise in distillate stockpiles, also signals cooling demand. Geopolitical tensions from Ukraine attacks on Russian refineries are providing some support, but concerns about oversupply from OPEC+ limit upside potential. The rate cuts from Bank of Canada and Gulf central banks may ease pressure on government, firms, and households but the impact on oil prices is limited by energy market volatility. The medium-term forecast is neutral due to offsetting factors, such as production concentration in Middle East and Russia versus slowing demand growth, leaving price direction uncertain.

47.summary: In the short term, WTI crude oil prices are expected to decrease. The latest EIA report reveals a significant draw in crude oil inventories, but the market's primary focus is on the increase in distillate stockpiles, which signals weakening demand. Furthermore, the Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates has been largely priced in. In the medium term, the WTI crude oil price is expected to move sideways. The recent events of Ukrainian drone attacks on Russian oil infrastructure coupled with expectations of a weaker dollar, may exert upward pressure on prices; at the same time, it has to be considered how a high production from OPEC+ countries is projected, the budget of Russia is in stress, and US relations with Colombia are souring.

48.summary: In the short term, WTI crude oil prices are expected to decline slightly, driven by the recent Fed rate cut, which has been priced into the market and is viewed as a risk management measure rather than a demand stimulus. The increase in distillate stockpiles also raises concerns about demand. In the medium term, WTI crude oil prices are expected to remain neutral, influenced by counteracting factors, including geopolitical tensions, potential supply disruptions from Russian attacks on energy infrastructure, and a large draw in U.S. crude inventories, offset by increasing OPEC+ production and concerns about the global economy. Technical analysis suggests consolidation.

49.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to decline in the short term due to concerns about the US economy and potential oversupply as highlighted by the builds in distillate inventories. The rate cut by the Federal Reserve indicates concerns about economic growth which also weighs on prices. The potential for further supply disruptions from Ukrainian attacks on Russian facilities provides some support, limiting the downside. In the medium term, prices are expected to remain range-bound, balancing geopolitical tensions, including those stemming from the Russia-Ukraine war and the Middle East, against increased OPEC+ output and the potential economic impact of higher U.S. trade tariffs.

50.summary: WTI crude oil prices are likely to experience downward pressure in the short term due to concerns about a slowing U.S. economy and persistent oversupply, as indicated by increasing distillate stockpiles, while historical data show a slightly negative trend as well. The Federal Reserve's rate cut and signals of further cuts have been largely priced in, and the focus has shifted to concerns about the U.S. economy which may limit the gains from any stimulus efforts. The medium term outlook is neutral with counteracting pressures that include the potential for supply disruptions due to Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure but also concerns about global economic growth. Also the announcement of EU on speeding up phase-out of Russian fossil imports may impact crude oil prices.

51.summary: WTI crude oil prices are expected to experience downward pressure in the short term due to weak U.S. fuel demand, rising distillate stockpiles, and concerns about a slowing U.S. economy despite the Federal Reserve's rate cut. In the medium term, prices are expected to trade range bound as these bearish factors are counterbalanced by geopolitical risks and potential disruptions to Russian oil supplies.

52.summary: Several factors are influencing the WTI crude oil price. On the bearish side, increased US distillate inventories, concerns about a slowing US economy, and potential oversupply are weighing on prices. The Fed's rate cut also signals concerns about economic growth. On the bullish side, geopolitical tensions due to Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy infrastructure, potential new sanctions on Russia, and a sharp drop in U.S. crude inventories are supporting prices. Overall, the market sentiment is mixed, with technical analysis suggesting some near-term bearish risks but also underlying support levels. Given these counteracting forces, I expect a slight short-term downward pressure but a neutral medium-term trend.
